body_content.explanation: a period of 24 hours, especially from twelve o'clock one night to twelve o'clock the next night:
examples: January has 31 days.
the days of the week
He runs five miles every day.
It took us almost a day to get here.
I saw him the day before yesterday.
We leave the day after tomorrow.
He was last seen alive five days ago.
They haven't been seen for days (= for several days).
I'll be seeing Pat in a few days/in a few days' time.
How's your day been? (= Have you enjoyed today?)
Have a nice day!
I must get some sleep - I've got a big day (= an important day) tomorrow.

body_content.explanation: used to refer to the period in 24 hours when it is naturally light:
examples: a bright sunny day
It rained all day.
These animals sleep during the day and hunt at night.

body_content.explanation: the time that you usually spend at work or at school:
examples: a normal working day
I work a seven-hour day.
We're having to work a six-day week to cope with demand.

body_content.explanation: a day when you do not have to work or do something that you normally do:
examples: I won't be in on Thursday - it's my day off.
Didn't I see you in the post office the other day?

body_content.explanation: used to talk about the present time, in comparison with the past:
examples: Vegetarianism is very popular these days.
In those days people used to write a lot more letters.

body_content.explanation: very soon, especially within the next few days:
examples: The baby's due any day now.
I prefer travelling by day.
The same problems keep coming up day after day.
You can hear the traffic from your room day and night.

body_content.explanation: every day, or more and more as each day passes:
examples: Day by day he became weaker.

body_content.explanation: If something changes (from) day to day, it changes often:
examples: The symptoms of the disease change from day to day.
I never know what I’ll be doing from one day to the next.
How did people communicate in the days before email?

body_content.explanation: up to and including the present moment:
examples: To this day nobody knows what happened to him.
